docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor Re ''Audit of V.A. Health Care Finds Millions Are Wasted'' (front page, Aug. 1): I have been enjoying outpatient care from the Department of Veterans Affairs' health care system for about a year. In addition to superior medical and dental care, I've received podiatry and optometry consultations, free eyeglasses, nutrition advice, prescription drugs for a small co-payment, and free blood-sugar monitoring equipment and instruction.
docs.abstract: Gordon J Rothstein letter, commenting on August 1 article on health care provided by Veterans Affairs Department, expresses satisfaction with outpatient care he has been receiving from department's system for past year

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton listened today to more than a dozen former welfare recipients recount their life-changing experiences working for companies including a CVS drugstore and the Bank of America. And he heard their employers praise them as highly reliable workers. Mr. Clinton joined the workers in celebrating a continued decline in the nation's welfare rolls and their transition to independence.

headline.main: Clinton Hears Success Stories of Ex-Welfare Recipients

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton attends forum in Chicago of Welfare to Work Partnership and listens to more than dozen former welfare recipients recount their life-changing experiences working for companies; he also hears their employers praise them as highly reliable workers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gunshot wounds cost the nation $2.3 billion a year in medical treatment, and almost half that sum is paid for with taxpayers' dollars, a study by a group of economists has found. The study, being reported today in The Journal of the American Medical Association, used data collected in 1994 to calculate the expense of treating the 134,445 gunshot wounds reported during that year. The total did not take into account other costs, like those of mental health treatment for victims or lost days of work.

headline.main: Annual Cost of Treating Gunshot Wounds Is Put at $2.3 Billion

docs.abstract: Study by group of economists finds that gunshot wounds cost nation $2.3 billion a year in medical treatment, and almost half that sum is paid for with taxpayers' dollars; study, in Aug 4 Journal of American Medical Association, uses data collected in 1994 to calculate expense of treating 134,445 gunshot wounds reported during that year; Dr Philip J Cook of Duke University is study's chief author (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Four months overdue, the Legislature completed passage of a $73.3 billion state budget early this morning that was incubated in partisan anger and hatched in weary compromise. It provides large increases in aid to schools and child care for the poor, and makes none of the cuts originally sought by Gov. George E. Pataki. The Senate passed the 11 huge spending bills making up the budget on Tuesday evening, while the Assembly did not approve the last of the bills until 1:33 A.M. today. As a result, the Legislature tied the record for tardiness in passing a budget, set two years ago, at 126 days late. State law requires approval of the budget before April 1, the start of the fiscal year, but New York has violated that law 15 years in a row, a record not approached by any other state.

headline.main: 4 Months Late, Albany Passes Budget for 2000

docs.abstract: New York State Legislature completes passage of $73.3 billion state budget that provides large increases in aid to schools and child care for poor and makes none of cuts originally sought by Gov George E Pataki; ties record for tardiness in passing budget, set two years ago, at 126 days late; budget mostly splits difference between proposals made early this year by Pataki and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, and final product resembles middle ground taken by Senate majority leader Joseph L Bruno; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The issues raised by ''Audit of V.A. Health Care Finds Millions Are Wasted'' (front page, Aug. 1) can be resolved simply: Close all the hospitals run by the Department of Veterans Affairs, sell or lease them, and then provide traditional health insurance.
docs.abstract: Letter from David Kanbar suggests closing all hospitals run by Department of Veterans Affairs, and providing veterans with traditional health insurance
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The issues raised by ''Audit of V.A. Health Care Finds Millions Are Wasted'' (front page, Aug. 1) can be resolved simply: Close all the hospitals run by the Department of Veterans Affairs, sell or lease them, and then provide...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Audit of V.A. Health Care Finds Millions Are Wasted'' (front page, Aug. 1): Other countries do not operate separate health systems for their veterans, because all their citizens are entitled to comprehensive health insurance and have access to the same public and private health care institutions. Probably because private health insurance in this country can be so easily lost, American veterans place their trust in the bogyman of American health policy: socialized medicine.
docs.abstract: Letter from Prof Uwe E Reinhardt on Aug 1 article on problems with Veterans Administration health care audit; suggests that veterans be entitled to same private health insurance coverage enjoyed by members of Congress
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Audit of V.A. Health Care Finds Millions Are Wasted'' (front page, Aug. 1): Other countries do not operate separate health systems for their veterans, because all their citizens are entitled to comprehensive health insurance...

docs.lead_paragraph: ABOUT once a week, Dr. Tom Coburn, a family practitioner in Muskogee, Okla., gets into a fight with an insurance company over some service he wants to provide to a patient. Nothing unusual there; a study released last week showed the vast majority of doctors struggling with managed care companies over what they would cover and what they would deny. But Dr. Coburn gets to engage in what may be every doctor's fantasy. ''When they deny me, I call 'em up and say, 'Do you know who you just denied? We're going to fix this for this patient. And you're exactly the reason you're going to get a law.' '' Very quickly, he said, the hapless bureaucrat realizes that Dr. Tom Coburn is also Representative Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, a leader in the fight for new patient protection in the era of managed care.

headline.main: Doctor in the House Is Still a Tough Advocate for Patients

docs.abstract: Public Lives column on Rep Tom Coburn of Oklahoma, who is one of handful of Republican doctors in House bucking leadership and much of party to pursue broader, tougher patients' rights bill than the one recently passed by Senate; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Businesses across America are bemoaning the shortage of workers, from highly skilled computer professionals to lower-paid clerks. Some New York City restaurateurs, calling it a ''crisis,'' are going so far as to offer health insurance to their waiters and establish training courses because they can't hire experienced personnel. And Wall Street sent stock prices reeling last week on the latest news that wages are up slightly more than expected. The market fears that the Federal Reserve will interpret any increase as a reason to be cautious and raise interest rates. The culprit in the minds of many is an unemployment rate of 4.3 percent, far lower than most economists believed possible without generating inflation. But, contrary to the prevailing wisdom, little has been better for the country than a dose of full employment. Americans have been unfamiliar with it for so long that they have forgotten how broadly beneficial it is.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Jeff Madrick claims full employment has been good for American economy, despite Wall Street's fears about rising interest rates; says that as incomes rise for all American workers, new, more vibrant markets are created for entrepreneurs; holds that willingness of Americans to work long and hard has been one of foundations of economic growth in 1990's (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LOOKING back on the legal imbroglio involving the $16 million dog, what really rankles is not the anxiety, or the agita, or even the bills. It's the sheer unfairness of it all. Because Clara was a complete cream puff. She looked like a canine blond bombshell, built on rather statuesque lines. But far from being brassy, Miss Clara was tiresomely timid, running from loud noises and cringing before smaller dogs. People often asked us if she was a big Wheaton terrier, or a small otter hound. We always called her a corn dog.

headline.main: Miss Clara, No Pit Bull, Is Finally Vindicated

docs.abstract: Leslie Eaton Coping column recounts $16 million suit filed against her mild-mannered dog, Clara, for ostensibly biting man during fracas with two German shepherds; Clara, old and in failing health, has been put to sleep; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS the baby boomers age and the oldest of them contemplate retirement, corporate purveyors of goods and services are increasingly taking notice. Advertising for products from bifocal contact lenses to Viagra attests to how the graying of America is forcing manufacturers and retailers to shift away from an obsession with youth.
docs.abstract: Fred Brock Seniority column on rise in advertising directed toward baby boomers as oldest ones move closer to retirement; offers sampling of books on senior matters, including Linda and Bob Kalian's The Best Free Things for Seniors, John F Walsik's The Late-Start Investor and Ken Dychtwald's Age Power: How the 21st Century Will be Ruled by the New Old; drawing (M)
